Find all values of $a$ for which the points $(0,0,0),$ $(1,a,0),$ $(0,1,a),$ and $(a,0,1)$ are coplanar.
inference:
The four points are coplanar if and only if the volume of the parallelepiped determined by the vectors
$$\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ a \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ a \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$$ is 0. The volume is given by the absolute value of the scalar triple product
\begin{align*} \left| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ a \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ a \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) \right| &= \left| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ a \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} (1)(1) - (a)(0) \\ (a)(1) - (0)(a) \\ (0)(0) - (1)(1) \end{pmatrix} \right| \\ &= \left| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ a \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ a \\ -1 \end{pmatrix} \right| \\ &= |(1)(1) + (a)(a) + (0)(-1)| \\ &= |1 + a^2| \end{align*}For the points to be coplanar, the volume must be 0, so $1 + a^2 = 0$.  This has no real solutions for $a$.

The determinant of the matrix with rows $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ a \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ a \end{pmatrix}$, $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is
$$\begin{vmatrix} 1 & a & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & a \\ a & 0 & 1 \end{vmatrix} = 1(1 - 0) - a(0 - a^2) + 0(0 - a) = 1 + a^3 = 0.$$
Thus $a = -1.$

Final Answer: $\boxed{-1}$

Thus,
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 0 & a \\ a & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & a & 1 \end{vmatrix} = 0.\]Expanding the determinant, we get
\begin{align*}
\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 0 & a \\ a & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & a & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= 1 \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ a & 1 \end{vmatrix} + a \begin{vmatrix} a & 1 \\ 0 & a \end{vmatrix} \\
&= 1((1)(1) - (0)(a)) + a((a)(a) - (1)(0)) \\
&= a^3 + 1.
\end{align*}Then $a^3 + 1 = 0,$ so $a = \boxed{-1}.$
